Acknowledge Employee Contributions: Recognize and appreciate your teamâ€™s collective efforts and individual contributions. Feeling valued helps prevent burnout

Prioritize Employee Well-Being: Make mental health and well-being a top organizational priority. Consider wellness programs, stress management training, and mental health days. Real ones, no tick box exercises!

Manage Workload: Ensure that workloads are reasonable and achievable. Encourage realistic expectations and avoid overburdening employees.

Foster a Positive Work Culture: Promote a supportive, inclusive, and respectful environment. Address toxic behavior promptly.

Provide Feedback & Transparency: Regular feedback helps employees understand their performance and areas for improvement. Transparency builds trust and reduces uncertainty.

Create a Psychologically Safe Environment: Encourage open communication, psychological safety, and trust. Employees should feel comfortable discussing their challenges without fear of repercussions.

Promote Work-Life Balance: Encourage employees to take breaks, use vacation days, and disconnect after work hours. Lead by example.

Train Managers: Equip managers with skills to recognize burnout signs, provide support, and facilitate work-life balance.

Review Policies: Evaluate policies related to workload, flexibility, and remote work. Adjust as needed to support well-being.
